docs.abstract: The musician on his platonic Tinder use and his addiction to an audience’s cheer.
docs.snippet: The musician on his platonic Tinder use and his addiction to an audience’s cheer.
docs.lead_paragraph: It has been 25 years since the “Blue Album” was released, and Weezer is having a resurgence. Your album “Pacific Daydream” is nominated for a Grammy this year; you just released the “Teal Album,” and the “Black Album” is coming out in March. Most important, your cover of Toto’s “Africa” hit more than 25 million streams on Spotify. Well, that started with a 14-year-old girl in Ohio who spammed us every day requesting us to cover Toto’s “Africa.” We let it play out for a few months and decided to release Toto’s “Rosanna.” Then, a week later, we put out “Africa.”

headline.main: Rivers Cuomo Prepackages His Internet Presence
headline.print_headline: Rivers Cuomo Prepackages His Internet Presence

docs.abstract: The pop historian Éric Zemmour has fashioned himself as an evangelist of French culture — and become a driving force for French conservatism.
docs.snippet: The pop historian Éric Zemmour has fashioned himself as an evangelist of French culture — and become a driving force for French conservatism.
docs.lead_paragraph: To follow Éric Zemmour around Paris this fall was to make a tour of the city’s slightly faded belle epoque salons. In September, after his latest book, “French Destiny,” was published, Le Figaro, France’s center-right daily paper, where Zemmour is a columnist, hosted a talk at the Salle Gaveau. A 1906 chamber-music hall, painted pale yellow and lined with parterre boxes, it is just two blocks from the presidential palace. “I’m not going to introduce Éric Zemmour,” his presenter told the sold-out hall, noting that you would have to live at the very edge of the universe to escape him.

headline.print_headline: ‘The Rights of Man Are the Death of France’

docs.abstract: As she watched her husband deteriorate, she pushed doctors to rethink what they were doing.
docs.snippet: As she watched her husband deteriorate, she pushed doctors to rethink what they were doing.
docs.lead_paragraph: “I guess it’s my time,” the 50-year-old man said quietly as his wife drove him home from his doctor’s office in southwest Houston. “No,” his wife responded sharply. “I won’t accept that. We’re going to get a second opinion.” To the patient, a software engineer and father of two teenage girls, it seemed as if this was the end of his 14 months of rapid decline from a robust man to this skeleton who needed a walker to get from car to door.

headline.main: The Patient’s Wife Thought Her Husband Was Being Treated for the Wrong Disease. She Was Right.
